example.original: Qau a ta ewar mis. Misan a ta man pi’i.
example.detailedTranslation: good 3sg top return sit sitreal 3sg top grass twine
example.translation: ‘So she sits down again. Sitting, she twines grass.’

example.original: Gang getopi gu med a, xabi mampelei utug met mi kunang masik namung gu ging.
example.detailedTranslation: 3sg 3sg.alienhat that take and then mango three take loc children male pl that 3plgive
example.translation: ‘He takes that hat of his and then takes three mangoes to give to the boys.’
‘Let me hit instead of (i.e. for) you.’
‘S/he killed two deer with bow and arrow.’
‘Where did the (several) goats go?’; NOT *‘Where did the goat go?’
‘Over there in the village people are making noise dancing lego-lego.’

example.original: A biran gi awan awan tasan gula’...
example.detailedTranslation: 3sg runreal go far.away far.away standreal finish

example.original: Hen mi ba Lius la hele.
Nei yo la mi ner te yo!
εi matε nu tang ta lamε eh.
example.detailedTranslation: boat be.large one sea on walk prog
example.translation: ‘A large boat is travelling on the sea.’
‘The lamp is shining for someone / at something.’
‘Sir, did you see (lit. meet) my child?’
‘I will tell him the way.’ (lit., ‘I will him about his road.’)

example.original: Pen ti matε sεl alɔ ʔabɔʔɔi.
ʔamɔ nu meja far mi eh.
example.detailedTranslation: cat one table below be.in prog

example.original: Gang ke’e na wang yawang kauwa.
Alma uh ok aniŋ=daŋ kai miok.
example.detailedTranslation: person clf two thusset=when cheer timetwo

example.translation: ‘... (he) climbed up (and) cut the branch twice...’

example.original: Pei ba mona de gekiŋ sesai.
example.translation: ‘The pig (that is) over there is still breathing.’
‘The tree branch is still over there.’
‘The tree branch is still moving over there.’
‘He went to this betel (palm) (which is) over here.’

example.original: … habukaŋ dikaŋ mi [ò nu do]NP=ŋ pa.
example.detailedTranslation: … 3.possthimble again take low.far art dem=loc go.low
example.translation: ‘… (he) again goes to take his thimble to down there.’
‘S/he eats fish down there (as you may know).’
‘That group of little houses down there is black.’
‘My house is as big as the one up there.’
‘S/he went up and is up there.’
‘There are dogs down there (away from the speaker).’

example.original: Ti taʔat ho mɔŋ bana mi tuf=eh.
example.detailedTranslation: tree dry dem level forest in stand=prog
example.translation: ‘The dry stick is standing over there in the forest.’
‘There are dogs lying down down there (in a directiondirection away from the speaker).’
‘Someone is selling those mangoes on the others mangoes (the upper group of mangoes) over there.’
‘That dog up here from the others down there is big.’
‘Those who are the ones visible down there will hand over the moko drums.’

example.original: [Aname ye daum]NP is taŋ tiʔaŋ kor iddia.
example.detailedTranslation: person one high.nvis.dem banyan on sleep snore proggo
example.translation: ‘Someone who is up there in a banyan tree sleeping and snoring away.’

example.original: Sinam bila taŋ misiŋ i habbaŋ pau ya saukaŋ pia.
example.detailedTranslation: spec.nvis.dem hill top sit 3pl.rflx.poss village low toward watch go.low.steep
example.translation: ‘(They) sat on the top of the mountain there and looked down at their village.’

example.original: Asaŋ sibaŋ tukka yallu paum iteri pau.
example.detailedTranslation: say driftwood short one low.nvis.dem proganchor low
example.translation: ‘Apparently, there’s a short (piece of) driftwood caught down there.’

example.original: Manne gaŋ awake siŋ usiŋ gar halli wa immia dau.
example.detailedTranslation: woman 3sg 4child this cradle 3with cry go.level proggo.high.steep high
example.translation: ‘His wife cradled her child while crying over him going back up there.’
‘Somebody was calling him from over there.’
‘Markus stumbled on the slope up (which is) up there.’

example.original: Ama rifirifi sei hel buku nu hewaalri.
example.detailedTranslation: person rdpthousand come.down.cont top land spec 3.locgather.in.compl
example.translation: ‘People came in thousands to that place.’

example.original: Atiga ma atiga tang tiggung (allang) hisnakkung
example.detailedTranslation: three come three on add (then) six

example.original: Yerig ma yerig taxa’ si a tiaam
example.detailedTranslation: three come three add sim 3sg six

example.original: Sua mi suang hai maiye talaama
example.translation: ‘If you add three to three, (it’s) six.’

example.original: Su me su wotte aning=bo taama

example.translation: ‘Discard two from five then there are three.’

example.original: Yeting nu ayoku=ng habel maiye hepot sua
example.translation: ‘If two is subtracted from five, the remainder is three.’

example.original: Yeting nu ayoku mia maiye sua
example.detailedTranslation: five spec two takedur if three
example.translation: ‘If two is taken from five, it is three.’
‘Take two from five thus there are three.’

example.original: Attu si gaunung me yasing allang (gang) ke alaku.
example.detailedTranslation: four that just on five then 3sg ten two
example.translation: ‘Five on just that four then (it’s) twenty.’

example.original: Ut ga’an tagan mayusan si, a qaar raq.
example.detailedTranslation: four that countreal comefive sim 3sg ten two
example.translation: ‘Count these four five times and it’s twenty.’

example.original: Bukbukna halakda nu ming yekna maiye kar ayoku.
example.detailedTranslation: rdpgroup.of.four 3.patcount.cont spec about five.times if ten two
example.translation: ‘If a group of four is counted five times, it is twenty.’

example.original: Ke anuku daai alaku allang yasing
example.detailedTranslation: ten one split two then five

example.original: Qaar nuk paxai get haraq si yusan.
example.detailedTranslation: ten one divide 3sgeye two sim five
example.translation: ‘Ten divided in two parts (lit. eyes), then (it’s) five.’

example.original: Kar nuku nu mi ayoku heyeng maiye yekyekna
example.detailedTranslation: ten one spec take two 3.locdivide if rdpgroup.of.five
example.translation: ‘If a ten is divided into two (you get) a group of five.’

example.original: Ye daai atiga, ye daai attu
example.detailedTranslation: one divide three one divide four

example.translation: ‘a third, a fourth, a tenth’ (lit. ‘Divide into three, four, ten’)
‘half, a third, a fourth/quarter, a tenth’
‘I eat a fourth of the mango.’, ‘I eat the mango in fourths.’
‘One and a half plates of rice’

example.original: Ha wou ga’an tu’un qaas namian
na be bo’oden solo ‘adi no’o menani?
example.detailedTranslation: 1sg mango half only eat can ornot
example.translation: ‘Can I only eat half a mango?’
‘Where did the (several) goats go?’; *‘Where did the goat go?’
‘His friends met him’/‘(He) met his friends.’ (*‘(He) met his friend.’; *‘(They) met their friend.’)

example.original: …, saku deing bias ol tamu poko dein=a gepai getai...
example.detailedTranslation: … adult pl usually child grandchild small pl=art 3make 3sleep
example.translation: ‘…, the adults would usually [do it] to make the children and grandchildren sleep…’

example.original: Nekarbau wari newai deing=na yeta legadar.
example.translation: ‘You watch out for my buffaloes and my goats.’
‘The chiefs were amazed.’ (*‘The chief is amazed.’)
‘A bunch of balls are spread out on the table.’

example.original: Uy masar gakon sib non gaʔan, ma tonaʔ.
example.detailedTranslation: person male 3sg.possshirt clean pl dem come collect
example.translation: ‘Those clean shirts of that man, collect them.’

example.original: sεi nun ho ʔuhuɲ ε bεŋ tanib
example.detailedTranslation: water pl def pour and other draw.water.from.well
example.translation: ‘Pour out that little bit of water and get some more from the well.’

example.original: *sεi nun alɔ ho ʔuhuɲ ε bεŋ tanib
example.detailedTranslation: water pl two def pour and other draw.water.from.well
example.translation: Intended: ‘Pour out the two bits of water and get some more from the well.’
‘A bunch of balls are spread out on the table.’

example.original: Bal ara atiga, kalla yasing, mea tang tiʔang.
example.detailedTranslation: ball large three small five table on set
example.translation: ‘Three large balls and five small balls are sitting on the table.’

example.detailedTranslation: someone goat pl many hold arrive
example.translation: ‘Were many [rather than few] goats brought here?’
‘Pick up the many coconuts.’ [situation: there are many coconuts in a pile of various kinds of fruits, and the order is to pick up these, not the rest]
‘Her children (lit. those her children) have died.’
‘Many of these (known) goats were chopped up.’
‘These (known) goats were chopped up by someone.’
‘the {specific group of} people {not some other group}’
‘Those villages make war together (against another village).’
‘…, her children and their associates come to mourn.’
‘Marten and his associates run away from me.’

example.original: [...oto heamakaang [ba homi mia]RC loku yo]NP mi pak mahoini
example.detailedTranslation: car 3.genperson rel 3.geninside in pl dem take cliff gatherpfv
example.translation: ‘...those people who were inside the car were taken over the [edge of the] cliff.’

example.original: [Sieng loku [ba uti mia]RC nu]NP sik bakoni mi melang sei.
example.detailedTranslation: rice pl rel garden in art pluck rip.off.pfvpfv take village come.down
example.translation: ‘Pluck off [all] the rice that is in the garden [and] take it down to the village.’
‘His children were six.’ i.e., ‘He had six children.’
‘His children were many.’ i.e., ‘He had many children.’

example.original: Hel loku abui yaa ut teak.
example.translation: ‘They went to the mountains to check the garden.’
Benny assoc garden go.to ‘Benny and his associates go to the garden.’
‘Different individuals called Benny go to the garden.’

example.original: Benny loku we / Benny we loku ut yaa.
example.detailedTranslation: Benny pl assoc / Benny assoc pl garden go.to
example.translation: ‘Two or more people called Benny go to the garden.’
near pl lit. ‘the near ones’; i.e. ‘neighbours’
lit. ‘the new ones’; i.e. ‘the newcomers, the Malays’
‘All its roots were pulled right up.’
‘Peter and the others were afraid to die.’

example.original: Ping pi mappu maiyang, lokke maiyang saiga si, gai keʔe maru si aname ging haggi kanna.
example.detailedTranslation: 1pl.incl 1pl.incl.poss fishpond place fishtrap place dem art 3.poss fish pl art person 3pl.act take already
example.translation: ‘We placed our fishponds, placed our fish traps, and then people took all the fish.’

example.original: [Aname marung] ging gaterannang dia wang pidding.
example.detailedTranslation: people pl they all go exist spread
example.translation: ‘All the people spread out [to look for them]’ (Lit. ‘All people they were all going spreading ...’)

example.original: *[Aname marung] ging kealaku dia wang pidding.
example.detailedTranslation: people pl they twenty go exist spread
example.translation: Intended: ‘All people they were twenty going spreading...’

example.original: ... kuya do sila nahang oro heya hepuyung loku do heafai.
example.detailedTranslation: ... bird dem much everywhere level 3.genmother 3.gensaliva pl dem 3.genswarm
example.translation: ‘Those birds were everywhere there, swarming over the saliva of his mother.’

example.original: Fat loku mi ba buot herei
example.translation: ‘Stow all the corn in the basket.’

example.original: Ama [nemea loku] tafuda takafi do nomi heukda
example.translation: ‘All my mangos got stolen, it really shocked me.’

example.original: ...a misan haliwai non daa nuan gom ma yiri u si,...
example.detailedTranslation: 3sg sitreal black.ant pl ascend cloth inside come crawl dist sim
example.translation: ‘...(while) he sat (unexpectedly many) black ants came crawling into his sarong,...’

example.original: Tumur lapong gai getati=sa, wor anta inipak lang=mi dein=a gepoing gedai medi aruku legeti.
example.detailedTranslation: east.wind wind 3.a 3stand=conj rock or sand beach=loc pl=art 3hit 3go.up take dry.land appl3lie
example.translation: ‘When the east wind blows, a mass of rocks and sand from the beach is lifted up and deposited on dry land (beyond the beach).’
‘Benny and his associates go to the garden.’
‘Different individuals called Benny go to the garden.’

example.original: Na yir non ma drom miaʔ.
example.translation: ‘I fill the drum with several containers of water.’

example.original: Teiwa non gaʔan itaʔa ma gi?
example.detailedTranslation: clan.name pl that.knwn where obl go
example.translation: ‘Where did that group of Teiwa [people] go to?’

example.original: Ga wosuksi=bo gafaa Takailubui geifu mauuh=a,...
example.translation: ‘They think that if they alone make war against the people of Takailubui,...’

example.original: Muut=ak nung iduka, ah=a nung alesei.
example.detailedTranslation: citrus=pl pl sweet cnct=spec pl sour
example.translation: ‘Some of these citrus fruits, others are sour.’

example.original: Nung gera yeiyaa ai Molpui wooi yete, nung gera yeeisol yeiyaa ai mane wooi yewete.
example.detailedTranslation: pl 3.contr 3.genreturn take M. 3.locto 3.gengo.up pl 3.contr straight 3.genreturn take village 3.loctowards 3.gengo.up.across
example.translation: ‘Some of them went home going up to Molpui, others went straight home going up across to the village.’

example.original: Naida Abui gelomu ong getenara, pang=sa tenong aumang dein=a Pantara gelomu ong getenara war Sawila gelomu.
example.detailedTranslation: 1pl.excl.top Abui 3language use 3teach dem=conj 1pl.inclfriend other pl=art Pantar 3language use 3teach and Sawila 3language
example.translation: ‘I will teach them Abui and other friends of ours will teach them Pantar and Sawila.’

example.original: Wenang marung hing yadda mising, nang natiʔang.
example.detailedTranslation: Mr pl pl not.yet sit I 1sgsleep
example.translation: ‘You all keep sitting, I’m going to sleep.’

example.original: Nagas qai non, tup pi gi ina.
example.translation: ‘My (female) friends, let’s get up to eat.’
‘Sir, did you see (lit. meet) my child?’
‘The dog ran off (was forced to run).’
‘[…] his father comes and wakes him.’

example.original: Wiil neng nuku di defeela hafik habele.
Kokda di haluol we hu ama feni.
example.translation: ‘When the younger one followed him, people killed (him).’

example.original: Rui ba tukola mia mai yo wan e hediki?
example.detailedTranslation: rat lnk hole be.indur be.proxpfv dem already before 3.locprickpfv
example.translation: ‘Has that rat that was in a hole already been stabbed?’

example.original: Rui tukola mia hare bataa mi hadike!
example.detailedTranslation: rat hole be.indur so wood take 3.patstabipfv
example.translation: ‘There are rats in the hole, so take a stick and run them through!’

example.original: Neng nuku laaklaaki ba me la dakaai yo eya!
example.detailedTranslation: man one walkwalkpfv and come just 3.patstumble dem exclam
example.translation: ‘A man walks along and stumbles there, whoops!’ [α-type prefix: do-]
‘The guy stands up and leaves.’ [α-type prefix: da-]

example.original: Lami saak nok gaserang maa we.

example.translation: ‘Don’t you forget to bring the bananas.’
‘A palm rib burns down/on (i.e., is consumed over time).’
‘The mountains are cold.’ (i.e., ‘In the mountains, it is cold.’)
‘I have cooled.’ (i.e., ‘My fever has come down.’)

example.original: Kri nuk ma bif goqai gatanan tup.
example.translation: ‘An old man comes and wakes up a small child.’

example.original: … ha gi ya’ siis nuk gauyan pin aria’.
example.detailedTranslation: 2sg go bamboo_sp. dry one 3search hold arrive
example.translation: ‘[…] You go look for dry bamboo to bring here.’

example.original: Uy masar nuk wa kri tumah.
example.detailedTranslation: person male one go old_man bump
example.translation: ‘A man is going and bumps into an old man.’

example.original: Kri nuk tewar wa tei tumah.
example.detailedTranslation: old_man one walk go tree bump
example.translation: ‘An old man walks and bumps into a tree.’

example.original: Bif goqai ma oma’ ta tas
example.translation: ‘A child comes and steps on his father.’

example.original: kri nuk ma moxoi muban ta tas [...]
example.detailedTranslation: old.man one come banana ripe on stand […]
example.translation: ‘An old man comes and steps on a ripe banana …’
‘An old man is standing cradling his child.’
